awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Bound-Bound and Bound-Free Opacities of Heavy Lowly-Charged r-Process Ions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is a collaborative effort between three major universities in the southeastern United States.  The research team will undertake a combined theoretical and experimental study of heavy elements that are produced in neutron star mergers, which have recently been shown to be gravitational wave sources.  The researchers will calculate the optical and infrared signatures of these elements and measure them in the laboratory to high accuracy.  Data on these elements are so limited that it is difficult to interpret observations of neutron star mergers.  Results from the study will allow astronomers to accurately interpret spectroscopic observations of neutron star mergers and to understand how heavy elements are formed in such mergers.  The project will provide students with research training, as well as opportunities to work on diverse but related topics at the three institutions.

The research team will study the so-called "second peak" elements --- Re, Os, Ir, Au, and Pt --- because these are predicted to be formed at relatively high abundances in neutron star mergers.  They will first calculate the atomic energy levels and transition probabilities of these elements using highly accurate and sophisticated quantum methods.  They will then measure the optical and infrared spectra of the elements to benchmark the calculations.  The result will be reliable properties and accurate spectral line lists, which can be used for the identification of these elements and determination of their abundances in the spectra of neutron star mergers.  This will also help shed light on the rapid neutron capture process --- or "r-process" --- involved in the synthesis of heavy elements in space.  This project will train graduate and undergraduate students in theoretical and experimental atomic physics, as well as astrophysics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project Collaborative Research: Bound-Bound and Bound-Free Opacities of Heavy Lowly-Charged r-Process Ions was a joint effort between researchers at Clemson University, Auburn University and the University of Georgia. The work was aimed at making an atomic physics study of elements relevant to neutron start merger events. In particular, the experimental measurements sought to measure the spectral signatures of the low-lying charge states of Au, Pt, Ir, Os and Re generated in laboratory-scale plasmas, while the theoretical calculations evaluated the photo-absorption cross sections of the first four charge states of these elements.

The NSF project (1815932) was awarded in 2018 with the experimental work centered on the electron beam ion trap (EBIT) facility at Clemson University and the compact toroidal hybrid (CTH) experiment at Auburn University. The calculational work was led by the University of Georgia. Initial loading tests at the EBIT facility led to promising new methods for side-loading metals directly into the plasma of that source; however, the majority of the experimental results came from the CTH experiment or, more recently, a hollow cathode lamp source. The results at CTH led to the development of a new loading method there where a probe coated with the element of interest is inserted into the plasma for ablation and spectroscopic study.

Measurements made at CTH focused on Au and Ni targets.  In the case of Au, over 40 previously unmeasured lines were observed for both Au I and Au II in the UV and visible ranges. These data are important for the interpretation of neutron star merger spectra, determinations of the abundance of r-process elements in stellar spectra, and as benchmarks for atomic structure calculations. In the generation of Au spectra in CTH a number of Ni spectral lines were also observed and utilized in the identification of Ni in cometary spectra. The Au and Ni results have been published in S.J. Bromley et al., Astrophys. J. S. 250, 19(2020) and S.J. Bromley et al., Planet. Sci. J. 2, 228(2021), respectively, and have appeared in numerous conference presentations. More recently, further Ni data as well as Pt data, obtained in a hollow cathode lamp. have been measured, with analysis and publication pending.

The calculational effort at the University of Georgia focused using the general-purpose relativistic atomic structure packages (GRASP) to obtain energy levels and transition probabilities for the low charge state elements in the Os isoelectronic sequence (Os I, Ir II, Pt III, Au IV, Hg V). The group was able to obtain line lists and expansion opacities for a range of these r-process elements, benchmarking them against existing data and calculations. In addition, emission spectra predictions were provided in cases relevant to kilonovae. These results were published in Z.S. Taghadomi, et al., Atoms 10, 94(2022). More recently this effort was extended to include the Re isoelectronic sequence (Re I, Os II, Ir III, Pt IV, Au V) and that work is submitted and under review.

The project has led to training of multiple graduate students and included the direct involvement of six undergraduate students in hands-on research, data analysis and the preparation and presentation of results to the broader scientific community.
